selected_quotes: When are randomised trials unnecessary? Picking signal from noise Burde vært pensum på psykologstudiet
Thanks @MccabeCJM @mariabustillos @NatalieBrender When are randomised trials unnecessary? Picking signal from noise@
When randomised trials are unnecessary and observations speak for themselves
When are randomised trials unnecessary? Picking signal from noise #BMJ Cited in post-debate Qs at #ECRMC13
Pity those #Melanoma trial designs must have missed THAT article. But the next chapter will be: when do they become unfeas…

citation.abstract: Although randomised trials are widely accepted as the ideal way of obtaining unbiased estimates of treatment effects, some treatments have dramatic effects that are highly unlikely to reflect inadequately controlled biases. We compiled a list of historical examples of such effects and identified the features of convincing inferences about treatment effects from sources other than randomised trials. A unifying principle is the size of the treatment effect (signal) relative to the expected prognosis (noise) of the condition. A treatment effect is inferred most confidently when the signal to noise ratio is large and its timing is rapid compared with the natural course of the condition. For the examples we considered in detail the rate ratio often exceeds 10 and thus is highly unlikely to reflect bias or factors other than a treatment effect. This model may help to reduce controversy about evidence for treatments whose effects are so dramatic that randomised trials are unnecessary.
citation.title: When are randomised trials unnecessary? Picking signal from noise

wikipedia.title: Randomized controlled trial
wikipedia.summary: A randomised controlled trial (or randomised control trial; RCT) is a type of scientific (often medical) experiment, where the people being studied are randomly allocated one or other of the different treatments under study.

source.description: The US National Academies Press (NAP) was created by the National Academy of Sciences to publish the reports of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine, operating under a charter granted by the Congress of the United States.
